div.style: padding: 2%; text-align: center; color: white; background-color: rgb(31, 73, 125);

div.p:
Our Food Service Department will continue to provide meals on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, from 9:00 to 11:00 a.m., to any child in need, aged 18 and under. This service will continue throughout the shutdown.
Thank you to Mrs. Megan Burny, our wonderful Food Service Staff, our Bus Drivers and other volunteers that have helped make this possible.

div.style: padding: 2%; text-align: center; color: white; background-color: rgb(31, 73, 125);

div.p: For up-to-date information on the Covid-19 virus in Michigan, please visit https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus

                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_0","title":"AP/SAT Testing Updates (updated 4/22/20)","content":"
Advanced Placement\n
Current AP Student Update:  
\nOn the day of your exam(s), please make sure that you are ready to start 30 minutes PRIOR to the exam time as you will need time to set up before starting the exam. The last day to drop your exam is Monday, April 27th. Email Ms. Uhl if this is what you decide. juhl@goodrichschools.org\n
\n
\n
\nThe College Board has announced at-home digital testing so AP students can still take this\nyear’s exam, even though schools are closed.   The exam content will focus on\nwhat most schools were able to complete by early March.  Students will be able\nto take their exams on any device they have access to—computer, tablet, or\nsmartphone.   They’ll also have the option to write their responses by hand and\nsubmit a photo. 
\n
\nClick the link for more details, available online
\n
•\tAP has cancelled all face to face testing.\n
•\tAP is creating 45 minute online tests
\n
\n•\tColleges support this solution and are committed to ensuring that AP students receive the credit they have worked this year to earn. For decades, colleges have accepted a shortened AP Exam for college credit when groups of students have experienced emergencies.
\n
\n•\tAP is offering refunds to everyone if they choose not to take exam
\n
\n•\tAP curricula are locally developed.  To be fair to all students, some of whom have lost more instructional time than others, the exam will only include topics and skills most AP teachers and students have already covered in class by early March.
\n
\n•\tStudents will be able to take these streamlined exams on any device they have access to—computer, tablet, or smartphone. Taking a photo of handwritten work will also be an option.
\n
\nBeginning March 26, 2020, students and schools have access to free, live AP review lessons, delivered by AP teachers from across the country. These daily lessons focus on reviewing the skills and concepts from the first 75% of the course. Hosted on the AP YouTube channel, these lessons will be recorded and available on-demand so teachers and students can access them any time. 
\n
\nThe\nCollege Board is also working to help students with connectivity issues\nget access to the tools they need to use the practice resources and take the\ntest as we understand that not all students have\naccess to the internet or a device. Students who need mobile tools or\nconnectivity should click the link to reach\nus directly to let us know. 
\n
\n\n
AP Test Security\n
•\tThe exam questions are designed and administered in ways that prevent cheating; we use a range of digital security tools and techniques, including plagiarism detection software, to protect the integrity of the exams.
\n
\n•\tScoring at-home work for an AP Exam is not new to the AP Program. For years the AP Program has received and scored at-home student work as part of the exams for the AP Computer Science Principles and AP Capstone courses.\n
 \n
SAT Testing\n•\tIn response to the rapidly evolving situation around the coronavirus (COVID-19), College Board is canceling the May 2, 2020 SAT and SAT Subject Test administration. Makeup exams for the March 14 administration (scheduled for March 28) are also canceled.\n
\n
\n•\tStudents who already registered for May, whose March test centers were closed, or who do not receive March scores because of any irregularities will receive refunds.
\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_1","title":"Senior Class Updates (updated 4/22/20)","content":"
2020 Top Ten Senior Scholars Announced\n
We would like to congratulate the Senior Scholars for the Class of 2020! The following students have earned the recognition of the Top Ten of their graduating class. It has been through many devoted hours, dedication, and work ethic that these students deserve special recognition. Senior scholars are determined by a formula including SAT score and GPA.   \n
\n  1\t\tRiley Moore
\n  2\t\tRalph Hof
\n  3\t\tMason Rich
\n  4\t\tJeremy Austin
\n  5\t\tOlivia O’Brien
\n  6\t\tNatalie Brown
\n  7\t\tKathryn Cartier
\n  8\t\tPaige Hunt
\n  9\t\tKatrina Stottmeister
\n10\t\tJoshua Austin\n\n
\n
\n
2020 Top Ten GPA\n
We'd also like to recognize the Top 10 GPAs of the Class of 2020.  They also have devoted many hours and shown outstanding dedication and work ethic to achieve this high honor.\n
\n1\tRiley Moore
\n2\tOlivia O’Brien
\n3\tAbigail Main
\n4\tNatalie Brown
\n5\tKathryn Cartier
\n6\tJoslynn Ridley
\n7\tMason Rich
\n8\tJeremy Austin
\n9\tMadison Voelker
\n10\tAllison Dolan
\n
\n\n
Prom Update\nAs mentioned our 2020 prom is rescheduled at this time for July 10th. Information on how to purchase tickets and other important information will be shared out in mid June.
\n
\n
Graduating seniors planning to attend Mott Community College in the Fall\nMott is offering virtual orientation and placement testing for the 2020 Fall semester. If you are interested please email Ms. Uhl by next, Wednesday April 26th at juhl@goodrichschools.org 
\n
\n
Required Senior Survey\nAs an extension of your EDP senior exit requirements you need to complete this quick survey! 
\nhttps://www.surveymonkey.com/r/2020GOODRICH
\n
\n
Local Scholarships\nYou can find the applications on the Counseling Office Page>Local Scholarships. The window is now open for seniors to complete the Genesee Go application at https://www.geneseego.org. 
\n
\n
Transcripts\nif you need a transcript sent, Parchment is being checked regularly. \n
\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_2","title":"HS Scheduling/Testing Out for 2020-21 (updated 4/22/20)","content":"
Prospective GCI Students for the 2020-21 School Year\nNext year’s enrollments are pending. We are awaiting direction from GCI about the next steps of the process. \n
\nTesting Out Registration\nIf you would like to attempt testing out of a class for the 2020-2021 school year please follow the link for more information about the process and registration. https://forms.gle/C4HWaZ56NmezaaRc7\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_3","title":"Athletic Dept (updated 4/22/20)","content":"
CONGRATULATIONS TO\n
 Maddie Voelker for being nominated to BCAM's Best of the Best (All-State) Team!  She averaged 23.6 points, 6 rebounds and 2 steals per game!
\n
\nGirls Basketball Coach of the Year:  Jason Gray
\nBoys Basketball Coach of the Year:  Gary Barns
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\nGoodrich Area Schools will be suspending all school related athletic activities (i.e. practices, contests, off season workouts, open gyms, banquets, etc.) until further notice.  
\n
\nWe do not encourage offsite workouts for any of our teams, clubs, etc. as we want to make sure that we are not putting any of our student-athletes at risk. The health and safety of our students continues to be our primary focus. \n

\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_4","title":"Meal Distribution & Central Office Hours","content":"
Meal Assistance During Shutdown\n
\nGoodrich Area Schools will be distributing meals for any child in need age 18 and under.  Breakfast and lunch items will be available for pick-up Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.  Pick up will be from 9:00 to 11:00 a.m., at Goodrich High School gymnasium entrance #7.  These meals are available for all children, 18 and under, free of charge
\n
\nPlease contact Mrs. Megan Burny, Food Service Director, at (810) 591-2236 if you are in need of meal assistance during the school shutdown period.
\n
\nClick for a list of meals offered in other communities for families during the school shutdown period. 
\n\n
\nAll District Buildings and Offices \nWill be closed from Monday, March 16 to Monday, April 13, 2020, in order to slow the spread of COVID-19.  
\n
\nCentral Office only will remain open in a very limited capacity in order to continue the essential functions of the district.  We will respond to emails and monitor phone calls at 810-591-2250.\n
\n
\nThe Bond Community Meeting scheduled for Monday, March 16th has been postponed to a later date TBD.
\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_5","title":"MS Band Trip to Cleveland","content":"
Dear 7th & 8th Grade Band Families, \n
With Governor Whitmer’s suspension of the school year, I regret to inform you that I have had to cancel our 7th & 8th-grade band trip to Cleveland. As soon as the Governor's announcement was made, I immediately contacted our travel agency and they have assured me that because we are still 50 days out from our trip, they should be able to get the majority (if not all) of our money back.\n
Please understand this process: you paid me, I paid the travel company, and the travel company used the money to pay the various vendors. They will, in turn, get a refund from the various vendors, and then send me a check. I will then be working with Goodrich Area Schools’ Central Office staff, to get you refunds as soon as the funds are available. \n
If you paid the third payment before the school closing by check, I will not cash those. They are still at school, uncashed. I will return them to you if you would like. If you paid the third payment before the school closure in cash, I can also return that to you. \n
Please know that I am very sad that our students won’t have this opportunity. I am working to get the most amount returned as possible.   \n
Thank you for your patience and understanding as all of these transactions take time. \n
Sincerely,\n
Mr. Hall","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_6","title":"8th Grade Washington DC & Cedar Point Class Trips ","content":"
Dear 8th Grade Families, \n
The safety of our students is our top priority. In consultation with local health department officials, and recommendations from Governor Whitmer and the CDC, we have made the decision to cancel the 8th grade trip to Washington DC. We did not make this decision lightly.  We know the many implications, financial and otherwise, that come with a decision such as this.\n
We have been working with Student Adventures and have been able to secure a refund for our families that did not purchase trip cancellation protection. This refund is above and beyond the contracted cancellation rate with the company.  You will soon be receiving an email from Student Adventures as to the amount of your refund. \n
Please know that we took all possible scenarios into consideration before we rendered this decision. We discussed options with the travel company regarding postponing the trip to a later date in lieu of cancelling. If we were to postpone, we felt the financial implications for those that were unable to attend were too great. Again, we believe the most prudent course of action is to cancel at this point and financially recoup as much as we can for our families.\n
In addition, we also need to cancel the class trip to Cedar Point. In the near future, a refund for the amount paid toward Cedar Point will be disbursed as well. \n
Thank you for your patience and understanding as all of these transactions take time. \n
Sincerely,\n
Mrs. Robb and Mrs. Czap \n
8th grade Sponsors","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl18_divTabs_7","title":"Oaktree/Reid Elementary","content":"
2nd Marking Period Report Cards for Oaktree and Reid are now available on ParentVue.  (3/20/20)\n
\n\n
\nResources available to our Reid families
\n• Google Classrooms for Developmental Kindergarten, Kindergarten and First Grade have been set up. You should have received a message from your child’s teacher on how to “enroll” in the grade level Google Classroom. If you did not, please reach out to your child’s teacher by email or remind. All staff emails can be found on the Goodrich Schools Website: goodrichschools.org 
\n
\n• If you are unable to get logged in to Google Classroom or you are unable to find your child’s student number, please let me know by email and I will contact you with assistance.
\n
\n• A new Google Classroom will be launched today titled “Intervention Team”. This “Classroom” will have additional resources from our Occupational Therapist; Speech Teacher, Kayricia Wagner; our Literacy Interventionist, Julie Semrau; our Special Education Teacher, Danielle Carrasco; and our Social Worker, Paige Millikin. If your child sees any of these support staff, please check out their Google Classroom. Resources include mindfulness activities, speech and language development games and more. Additionally, all our Reid Families are welcome to check out the extra resources provided by the intervention team. Please follow the directions sent by your child’s teacher to navigate to Google Classroom. Then use the following code to enter the “Intervention Team” Classroom: p74o3te
\n
\n
\n
\n Oaktree and Reid Spring Parent/Teacher Conferences have been cancelled.  A decision on rescheduling is forthcoming.","active":false,"disabled":false}],// required,

div.div:
SOCIAL & EMOTIONAL RESOURCE HELP LINE
591-HELP (591- 4357)
Students or parents can call this line and be connected with a licensed professional from the GISD (social workers, counselors, therapists)
Callers are able to leave a message after hours and will receive a call back during operational hoursof 9:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m., Monday - Friday.
The licensed professional answering the call may assist in the following areas:
Provide support to assist students and parents dealing with stressful situations.
Provide assistance in accessing resources and getting the help students/families need.
Refer students/families to other local and county agencies for additional support. It is important to note that the intention of the phone line is not to provide telehealth therapy. If it is deemed that therapy may be needed, families will be assisted through a referral process.

Passwords are:  6-digit student number and 2 initials (lowercase) 
\n\tExample:  99####ft  or 00####hm

\n**Some twin or sibling situations may have a 1 with their login info.  
\n

Genesee Intermediate School District curriculum and instructional staff have compiled the Genesee ISD Online Educational Resources (opens in a new window)for parents and educators to help keep children engaged and learning during the COVID-19 pandemic shutdown.



Additionally, the following activity packets for grades K-8 are available for educators to share and parents to use at home:

Kindergarten

Grade 1

Grade 2

Grade 3

Grade 4

Grade 5

Grade 6

Grade 7

Grade 8






Enrichment Learning Resources  
CPS (Chicago Public Schools) prepared educational enrichment activities to support student learning while schools are closed due to COVID-19. The packets include a range of activities that students can work on independently or with help from an adult.  They have willingly shared their resources with districts across the country.


<ul style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 25px; padding: 0px 0px 0px 40px; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); >
    
    
Independent Projects
    These projects cover a range of different topics and skills. They may be spread out over multiple days.
    
Enrichment Activities
    These activities are organized into Read, Write, Move, Design, and Solve categories so you can engage with your child in many different ways while at home.
    Some of these options are digital and require Internet access.

Students may work through these resources over multiple days and in any order. If you are unable to print these materials or use them digitally, you can go to any school-based food distribution site and pick up a printed packet.
Download your child's grade level packet below:

 ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl37_divTabs_3","title":"Middle School/High School","content":"
Many classrooms are already using Khan Academy to enrich student learning.  Khan Academy offers practice exercises, instructional videos, and a personalized learning dashboard that empower learners to study at their own pace in and outside of the classroom. Khan Academy tackles math, science, computer programming, history, art history, economics, and more.  It offers practice exercises, instructional videos, and a personalized learning dashboard that empower learners to study at their own pace in and outside of the classroom.

As a mission-focused non-profit, it is Khan Academy’s duty to do our part to ensure students keep learning amidst the school closures. We also want to support teachers and parents to the best of our ability as we navigate this crisis together.



These schedules are meant to be templates that you could adopt as is or copy and modify to better suit the needs of your children. As you see in the schedules below, Khan Academy does have self-paced, interactive content--exercises, videos and articles--for students in every grade and in most major subject areas. It is all free and non-commercial and is made possible by philanthropic support from people like you.  We are also having daily (weekdays) 9am PST/12 EST live streams on Facebook and YouTube for students.

Get the student schedules in another language here.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl37_divTabs_6","title":"Advanced Placement (AP) Resources","content":"
    
        

            
            
 
            
        
        

            
            

            
                
                    

                        
                        

                        
                            
                                

                                    
                                    
Modern States offers AP courses, too 
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                        
                    
                
            
            
            
        
        

            
            

            
                
                    

                        
                        

                        
                            
                                

                                    
                                    
You probably know Modern States as the leading college program for learners who take courses and then earn free college credit through CLEP exams. But did you know Modern States also offers Advanced Placement (AP) courses taught by professors from MIT, Rice, Purdue and other top universities?

                                    

                                    High school students can use all or part of each Modern States AP course to prepare for an AP exam this spring. Due to the coronavirus, AP exams will be offered online rather than in-person in high schools. The online exams, administered by The College Board, will be 45 minutes long with written answers and no multiple-choice questions.

                                    

                                    High school students may take the Modern States courses, as well as the AP exams, from anywhere on any device that connects to the Internet, including a cell phone.
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                        
                    
                
            
            
            
        
        

            
            

            
                
                    

                        
                        

                        
                            
                                

                                    
                                    

                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                        
                    
                
            
            
            
        
        

            
            

            
                
                    

                        
                        

                        
                            
                                

                                    
                                    
                                        
                                            

                                                
                                                
                                                    
                                                        

                                                            
                                                            

                                                            
                                                        
                                                        

                                                            
                                                            
The AP Environmental Science exam focuses on the living world and evolution.
                                                            
                                                        
                                                    
                                                
                                                
                                            
                                        
                                    
                                    
                                    
                                    
 
                                    
                                    
                                    
                                        
                                            

                                                
                                                
AP Environmental Science – Part 1: The Living World
                                                
                                            
                                            

                                                
                                                
The first course in a comprehensive series designed to prepare you for the AP Environmental Science exam, focusing on the living world and evolution.
                                                
                                            
                                        
                                    
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                        
                    
                
            
            
            
        
        

            
            

            
                
                    

                        
                        

                        
                            
                                

                                    
                                    

                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                        
                    
                
            
            
            
        
        

            
            

            
                
                    

                        
                        

                        
                            
                                

                                    
                                    
Through an existing partnership with edX – the learning platform founded by Harvard and MIT – Modern States offers the major AP courses, including Biology, Calculus, English Literature, Environmental Science, Economics, Physics and others. While high school students can take the courses to get ready for the upcoming exams, others can take them to learn from some of the country’s very best professors.

                                    

                                    When you click on a Modern States AP course, it will take you to the edX website, where the AP courses reside. Every AP course is designed to help you prepare for and improve performance on an AP exam. That’s the same approach used in Modern States CLEP courses.

                                    

                                    Since many high schools closed early due to the pandemic, the AP exams will only cover material through early March. The College Board will announce the exam schedule and additional information on April 3. But if you’re going to take one or more AP exams this spring, you can get started studying using Modern States AP courses now.

                                    

                                    How do Modern States AP courses work?
                                    
                                        
Click “Course Catalog” on ModernStates.org 
                                        
Scroll down to the AP courses 
                                        
Follow the prompts to register for a course 
                                        
Complete the coursework provided 
                                        
Pass an online AP exam and earn college credit 
                                    
                                    
We encourage you to contact us with any questions at info@modernstates.org or connect with peers in our Facebook group. And if you’re taking an AP exam this spring, we wish you good luck.
                                    
 
                                    
                                
                            
                        
                        
                        
                    
                
            
            
            
        
    


","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl37_divTabs_7","title":"Music","content":"


Detroit Symphony Orchestra

Music Education Resources for Students, Teachers and Families

If you are looking to maximize learning at home, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra is committed to supporting you with free videos, resources, and activities that explore the arts, so closed schools and social distancing doesn't mean losing access to music education.

Educational Concert Webcasts and Resource Guides

Our Classroom Edition webcasts of Educational Concerts are available to stream for free any time. These concerts are great tools for students to learn critical listening skills while exploring orchestral music, music history, and composers. Each concert has an accompanying Resource Guide full of lessons and activities based on NAfME and Common Core standards.

For example, check out our 2018 performance of A Symphony of Science and learn about how physics and anatomy combine to create music.

YouTube and DSO Replay

In addition, our YouTube channel and DSO Replay have tons of full concerts and concert excerpts. Students can listen to pre-concert talks with conductors to learn about the music and its history, then listen for what they learned in the corresponding DSO performance. 

Pinterest

Head to our Education Resources board on Pinterest for great worksheets, infographics, and activities families can explore together. We will be expanding our resources each week, so keep checking back for new materials!

\nClick here for the Run Club Healthy Habits Challenge","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl43_divTabs_1","title":"Mi Child/Healthy Kids Health Insurance","content":"
Medicaid Outreach\n
MI Child and Healthy Kids hotline at 1.888.988.6300
\nor apply online at www.michigan.gov/michild.\n
Many Michigan children go without health care because they have no insurance coverage. Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has programs available that can help families with their children’s health care needs. Families without insurance should be encouraged to apply and know what benefits they may receive.\n
Medicaid\n
Medicaid is health care coverage for eligible, low-income people and working families.
\n This includes families, children, women who are pregnant, and persons under the age of 21.
\n Medicaid also offers help to people who are blind, disabled or age 65 or over.
\n The Medicaid Application is good for accessing multiple applications, including Healthy Kids, \n
MIChild, and Medicaid\n
 The web address for the on-line application is www.michigan.gov/michild.
\n There are several organizations with staff to assist with the application process. In Genesee County, contact the Greater Flint Health Coalition at 810-232-2228 and ask for Maria or Taylor.\n
Health Care Programs\n
Healthy Kids\n
 is a Medicaid health care program for low-income children under age 19 and for pregnant women of any age.
\n There is only an income test.
\n There is no monthly premium for Healthy Kids.
\n Most children who are eligible for Healthy Kids are enrolled in a Medicaid health plan.
\n Healthy Kids provides a comprehensive package of health care benefits including hearing, vision, dental, immunizations, well child visits, emergency care, and mental health services.
\n There are several organizations with staff to assist with the application process.\n
MIChild\n
 is a health care program administered by the Department of Health and Human Services.
\n It is for the low income, uninsured children of Michigan’s working families.
\n There is only an income test.
\n Like Healthy Kids, MIChild is for children who are under age 19.
\n There is a $10 per family monthly premium for MIChild. The $10 monthly premium is for all of the children in one family.
\n The child must be enrolled in a MIChild health and dental plan in order to receive services.
\n Beneficiaries receive a comprehensive package of health care benefits including hearing, vision, dental, immunizations, well child visits, emergency care, and mental health services.
\n For more information and an application, contact MIChild at 1-888-988-6300 or the MIChild information website.
\n There are several organizations with staff to assist with the application process.\n
What can you do?\n
Encourage families without insurance to apply. DHHS will determine which program a family qualifies for. Families need to know that it will not hurt their chances of receiving other services if they or their children use health care benefits.
\n
\n\n
Application Website in English, Spanish, Arabic and for those with Hearing or Speech Disabilities.
\n
\n\n
Free or low-cost health coverage for children under the age of 19, or pregnant women of any age. Call the MI Child and Healthy Kids hotline at 1.888.988.6300 or apply online at www.michigan.gov/michild.
\n
\nDownload .pdf version of this document\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl43_divTabs_2","title":"Michigan Cares Parent Resources","content":"There's no playbook for parenting (or teaching!) during a pandemic.  During a global pandemic, it’s easy to focus on logistical concerns. There are certainly plenty of them. But your emotional health — and the emotional health of our students — deserves attention, too. 
\n
\nOur students react to what they see on the news as well as how they see us react to sudden unemployment, sickness, and the loss of life that COVID-19 threatens. If we’re not careful to pay attention to our collective well-being, we may end up with a statewide mental health crisis on our hands.
\n
\nThere’s no playbook for parenting or teaching during a pandemic, but our Michigan Cares Portal can help both parents and educators support their students’ emotional and mental well-being while managing their own emotions and responsibilities.  
\n
\nClick for more information:
\n
\n
","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl43_divTabs_3","title":"Mental Health America Resources","content":"As the number of cases of COVID-19 increase, so does the associated anxiety.
\n
\nFor the general public, the mental health effects of COVID-19 are as important to address as are the physical health effects. And for the one in five who already have mental health conditions – or the one in two who are at risk of developing them – we need to take personal, professional, and policy measures now to address them.
\n
\nTo aid individuals and communities during this time, MHA has compiled a range of resources and information.
\n
\nPlease click below for information in any of these areas and more:
\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl43_divTabs_4","title":"Wellness Related Resources for Schools and Families","content":"

\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl43_divTabs_6","title":"Talking To Kids About the Coronavirus","content":"
Talking to Kids About the Coronavirus by Rachel Ehmke\n
Kids worry more when they're kept in the dark\n
\n
\n\n
\nNews of the coronavirus COVID-19 is everywhere, from the front page of all the papers to the playground at school. Many parents are wondering how to bring up the epidemic in a way that will be reassuring and not make kids more worried than they already may be. Here is some advice from the experts at the Child Mind Institute.
\n
\nDon’t be afraid to discuss the coronavirus. Most children will have already heard about the virus or seen people wearing face masks, so parents shouldn’t avoid talking about it. Not talking about something can actually make kids worry more. Look at the conversation as an opportunity to convey the facts and set the emotional tone. “You take on the news and you’re the person who filters the news to your kid,” explains Janine Domingues, PhD, a child psychologist at the Child Mind Institute. Your goal is to help your children feel informed and get fact-based information that is likely more reassuring than whatever they’re hearing from their friends or on the news.\n
\n
\nBe developmentally appropriate. Don’t volunteer too much information, as this may be overwhelming. Instead, try to answer your child’s questions. Do your best to answer honestly and clearly. It’s okay if you can’t answer everything; being available to your child is what matters.\n
\n
\nTake your cues from your child. Invite your child to tell you anything they may have heard about the coronavirus, and how they feel. Give them ample opportunity to ask questions. You want to be prepared to answer (but not prompt) questions. Your goal is to avoid encouraging frightening fantasies.\n
\n
\nDeal with your own anxiety. “When you’re feeling most anxious or panicked, that isn’t the time to talk to your kids about what’s happening with the coronavirus,” warns Dr. Domingues. If you notice that you are feeling anxious, take some time to calm down before trying to have a conversation or answer your child’s questions.\n
\n
\nBe reassuring. Children are very egocentric, so hearing about the coronavirus on the news may be enough to make them seriously worry that they’ll catch it. It’s helpful to reassure your child about how rare the coronavirus actually is (the flu is much more common) and that kids actually seem to have milder symptoms.\n
\n
\nFocus on what you’re doing to stay safe. An important way to reassure kids is to emphasize the safety precautions that you are taking. Jamie Howard, PhD, a child psychologist at the Child Mind Institute, notes, “Kids feel empowered when they know what to do to keep themselves safe.” We know that the coronavirus is transmitted mostly by coughing and touching surfaces. The CDC recommends thoroughly washing your hands as the primary means of staying healthy. So remind kids that they are taking care of themselves by washing their hands with soap and water for 20 seconds (or the length of two “Happy Birthday” songs) when they come in from outside, before they eat, and after blowing their nose, coughing, sneezing or using the bathroom. If kids ask about face masks, explain that the experts at the CDC say they aren’t necessary for most people. If kids see people wearing face masks, explain that those people are being extra cautious.\n
\n
\nStick to routine. “We don’t like uncertainty, so staying rooted in routines and predictability is going to be helpful right now,” advises Dr. Domingues. This is particularly important if your child’s school or daycare shuts down. Make sure you are taking care of the basics just like you would during a spring break or summer vacation. Structured days with regular mealtimes and bedtimes are an essential part of keeping kids happy and healthy.\n
\n
\nKeep talking. Tell kids that you will continue to keep them updated as you learn more. “Let them know that the lines of communication are going to be open,” says Dr. Domingues. “You can say, ‘Even though we don’t have the answers to everything right now, know that once we know more, mom or dad will let you know, too.’”","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl43_divTabs_7","title":"How to Prevent the Spread of Covid-19","content":"
Use good hygiene practices to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and other respiratory diseases.\n•\tStay home if you are sick, and advise others to do the same. 
\n•\tAlways cover coughs or sneezes with a tissue or sleeve. 
\n•\tAvoid close contact with people who are sick. 
\n•\tAvoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands. 
\n•\tWash your hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds. Use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and warm water are not available. 
\n•\tClean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces. 
\n \n
\nIt’s not too late to get your flu shot! \nWhile the influenza vaccine does not protect against COVID-19 infection, it can help keep you healthy during the flu season.
\n \n
\nReview travel advisories before planning travel.\nAlways review travel advisories from the federal government when planning personal and business travel. Review CDC.gov/Travel for destinations with risk of community spread of COVID-19.
\n \n
\nShare accurate information.\nAlways share accurate information about a virus and its spread. It is important to remember that stigma and discrimination occur when people associate an infectious disease, such as COVID-19, with a population or nationality. COVID-19 does not target people from specific populations, ethnicities or racial background. Suspected discrimination can be reported to the Michigan Department of Civil Rights.
\n \n
\nThis is a rapidly evolving situation\nFor the latest information, please see Michigan.gov/Coronavirus or CDC.gov/Coronavirus. The CDC has provided guidance for preventing the spread of COVID-19 in communities including businesses, community- and faith-based organizations, and childcare organizations and schools.

To Our Martian Families – \n
If you are interested in using a district Chromebook device for your student(s) to complete school work for the remainder of this 2019-2020 school year, please watch for our next distribution date.   You may also email us at our parent/student tech help email at TechHelp@goodrichschools.org  to set up an alternative pick-up time.  Please note that times are limited as we work to comply with the Stay Home, Stay Safe mandate we are currently under.\n
The Chromebooks being distributed are used in the classrooms throughout the district during the year.  They are wireless laptops that make use of cloud-based applications, so a wireless internet connection or hotspot is necessary.  \n
If you are not able to use a Chromebook at this time, we also offer paper packets if that would benefit your child more.\n
At this time, we are able to provide a maximum of 2 devices per family.  \n
The Device Distribution area will be at the Central Office, Door #11 on the west side of the high school building.  Being mindful of the current social distancing and cleaning guidelines (and the weather), please follow these steps to receive your device:\n\n    
When you are next in line, pull up and park by the curb in front of Door #11.\n    
One adult only please go to the table that will contain the device, an AC power adapter and two copies of the Student Device Checkout agreements.   \n    
Please print your name and sign one Device Checkout agreement, listing the school-aged children in your family.  \n    
Put one copy of the Checkout agreement into the basket on the table and keep one copy for your records.  \n    
Return to your vehicle and move ahead so the next vehicle in line can pull up to receive their device.\n\n
If you wish to bring your own pen to sign the contract, feel free to do so.  We will have hand sanitizer for you to use and will wipe the table that the device is placed on throughout the distribution period.   All Chromebooks were sanitized prior to distribution.\n
A copy of the Student Device Checkout agreement is available here for you to read before you decide to pick up a device.  You do not need to print out or sign this ahead of time – we will have your paperwork ready for you when you arrive.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_1","title":"Paper Packets for Home (4/9/20)","content":"
Hello Parents -\n
We wanted to provide some clarification regarding paper packets: \n\n    
Paper packets will be available for students who are unable to connect to learning through their Google Classroom due to not having internet or device access. \n    
Paper packets are not additional activities or resources.  \n    
Additional enrichment resources are available on the district website resource page by grade level.  If you do not have internet or device access and you would like a packet for additional enrichment, please contact your building principal. \n    
In order to properly prepare for those truly needing paper packets, please email your building principal by Monday, April 13 at 8:00 AM.  \n    
Please only pick up a paper packet if it is needed and you have notified your building principal.  We want to be sure copies are available for those who need them. \n\n
Additionally, please note that our Continuous Learning Plan is not intended for students to be on a device for an extended period of time.  If you have multiple children, we suggest setting up a time slot for each to use the device to review weekly assignments and complete any work.  Our teaching staff is mindful of the recommended learning/activity times for each grade level listed in the previous parent communication. \n
Jasan Bryan, Oaktree Principal - jbryan@goodrichschools.org\n
Beth Millerschin, Reid Principal - bmillers@goodrichschools.org\n
 \n
 \n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_2","title":"Video Message from Your Goodrich Administrators (4/9/20)","content":"
Please click on the link below for an important video message from your Goodrich Area Schools administration:\n
https://youtu.be/TN_vmrB7pLc\n
Thank you.","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_3","title":"Elementary Family Letter-Continuous Learning Plan (4/9/20)","content":"Greetings Elementary Students and Families,
\nIt’s hard to believe that our in-person time together and traditional learning has come to an end for this academic school year. Our goal as a district is to stay connected to the community, while meeting the academic, social and emotional needs of our students. We recognize that the family is the child’s first teacher. We honor the importance of each family member’s expertise in determining what works best for their children and family during this
\nunprecedented time. We are not creating or replacing the teacher; rather, we are supporting
\nfamilies in a partnership for learning. We are seeking to strengthen the already existing
\npartnership between teachers and families and to assist families as they embrace their role in
\nsupporting their child’s learning. To do this, families may be asked to, when possible, spend
\ntime with their children, play with their children, share their unique talents and interests, and
\nengage in suggested learning opportunities.
\n
\nAs we make the transition from in person to remote learning, our district has been working
\ndiligently to create a plan that allows for equitable learning for all students. Below is an
\noverview of that plan. Please note that as the executive order indicated, all plans must be
\nsubmitted to local intermediate school districts. Our plan is in the process of being submitted
\nand once approved, will be posted on our district’s website. We are implementing our plan
\nbeginning Monday, April 13 with the understanding that based on feedback from the
\nIntermediate School District or issues encountered along the way, this plan may need to be
\nadjusted.
\n
\nHighlights of our DK-5 Elementary Continuous Learning Plan are listed below.
\n Teachers will provide online activities and learning through Google Classroom for
\nessential core content skills not yet taught this year. For those unable to access digital
\nlessons, printed materials are available to keep all learners on track. (see below)
\n Weekly learning plans will be posted on Mondays. These plans will include target skills
\nin the core areas. Six assignments will be posted per week. These assignments are to
\nbe completed and submitted back to the teacher for feedback.
\n Teachers will be keeping track of assignment participation. Students are expected to
\ncomplete assignments to the best of their ability.
\n Specials and Science (Oaktree)
\no A weekly lesson for music, art, and gym will be posted in the “Specials” Google
\nClassroom on Monday.
\no Oaktree students will have a weekly lesson posted in their grade level’s Science
\nGoogle Classroom.
\n Students are free to work on the specials and science lessons throughout
\nthe week or wait until Friday when they do not have assignments from
\ntheir homeroom teacher.
\n It is recommended that students work daily according to the following schedule: grades
\nDK-1 30-45 minutes, grades 2-3 45-60 minutes, and grades 4-5 60-75 minutes.
\no These ranges are set in place to provide a guide for our families with the
\nunderstanding that parents are working from home, students are sharing devices
\nand families may be dealing with illness. If you are looking for further resources,
\nplease refer to the district website for many alternative, extension activities: Stay
\nHome/Stay Safe Updates and Family Resources
\n Each classroom teacher will have office hours Monday - Thursday. Teachers will be
\navailable by email, Google Classroom, Remind or other means of communication to
\nrespond to questions or help when needed. Individual teachers will communicate these
\noffice hours to their families. Teachers will be available throughout the week but may
\nnot be able to respond as quickly.
\n Teachers will connect with students by video means for opportunities to “see”
\nclassmates and make connections.
\nPaper Packet Information:
\n For students in grades DK-5, paper packets will be made available outside your child’s
\nbuilding beginning Monday April 13th. These packets are labeled by grade/teacher, and
\nyou can pick them up at your convenience.
\n Learning packets will be provided on a weekly basis.
\n Learning packets will include the weekly agenda of assignments for each grade level
\n(focused on the core academic areas) and any resources needed to complete those
\npackets.
\n Upon completion of assignments in the paper packets, please take a photo of the
\nassignments and email them to the assigning teacher.
\n
\nDon’t hesitate to contact us with questions, comments or concerns. We are here to partner
\nwith you in this journey. We are just asking everyone to put forth a good faith effort. If we can
\nbe of any help to you or your family during this time, please let us know!
\n
\nJasan Bryan, Oaktree Principal
\nBeth Millerschin, Reid Principal
\n
\nFrom our teachers:
\nI will teach you in a room.
\nI will teach you now on zoom.
\nI will teach you in my house.
\nI will teach you with my mouse.
\nI will teach you here or there.
\nI will teach because I care.
\nSo just do your very best.
\nAnd do not worry about the rest!","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_4","title":"Secondary Family Letter - Continuous Learning Plan (4/9/20)","content":"Goodrich Area Schools Secondary 6-12 Continuous Learning Plan
\n
\nGreetings Secondary Students and Families,
\n
\nIt’s hard to believe that our in-person time together and traditional learning has come to an end for this academic school year. Our goal as a district is to stay connected to the community, while meeting the academic, social and emotional needs of our students. As we make the transition from in-person to remote learning, our district has been working diligently to create a plan that allows for equitable learning for all students. Below you will find key concepts of the plan pertaining to your child(ren) and families.
\n
\nLast week saw some major changes in regards to the way that we are providing instructional content.  As you know, Governor Whitmer, through her Executive Order, has required us to develop a Continuous Learning Plan for the remainder of the school year. This plan will give opportunities for students to continue their learning. Teachers understand the requirements of the revised teaching and learning essentials, “grading” system, and how they will be working with our families and students going forward.  The expectation is that students are completing the assigned weekly work for all of their classes. 
\n
\nTeachers will be sharing with students and families by 9:00am starting on April 13th what the Continuous Learning Plan looks like in their new “virtual” classroom. Please know that, despite our best efforts, we cannot recreate every subject into a remote learning platform. As a result, activities will focus on learning the essential skills needed to keep students moving forward and prepare them for next year’s educational experience.
\n
\nPlease note that as the executive order indicated, all plans were to be submitted to local intermediate school districts starting April 8, 2020. Our plan has been submitted and, once approved, will be posted on our district website. The Continuous Learning Plan does not attempt to recreate the six hours of instruction that students typically receive at school each day. We knew from the first moment of planning that this would not be possible. We also understand that every household dynamic is different.
\n
\nStarting Monday, it’s fair to say that learning will be different. We’re going to make the most of this challenge and show our students that we care about them by doing our best to keep them learning. As humans, we all love our routines. We crave normalcy, but we’ll adapt and do everything possible to help our students thrive. We also know that we live in a generous community that will come together to help our families in need. To that end, we have created the following recommended learning time range:
\n
\nGrade Level Recommended Time Range
\nDK-1 30-45 minutes/day
\n2-3 45-60 minutes/day
\n4-5 60-75 minutes/day
\n6-8 30-45 minutes/day per class (recommending 3 classes a day) Total: 90 - 135 minutes/day
\n9-12 30-45 minutes/day per class (recommending 3 classes a day) Total: 90 - 135 minutes/day
\n
\nTo help students and families structure their learning time, the following schedule is proposed as a guide. Please know that teachers won’t be teaching in traditional assigned hours, but they will be providing material for students to work on for the day/week. Deadlines for work will still be given and should be followed.
\n
\nStudents, to help you structure your time, we are proposing you follow the schedule below:
\n Monday / Wednesday - Hours 1st, 2nd, and 3rd
\n Tuesday / Thursday - Hours 4th, 5th, and 6th
\n Friday - Carryover, complete work not previously completed for the week – and/or review feedback from teachers and make adjustments to your learning/understanding
\n
\n For middle school students: elective rotation course work will be offered as applicable, as not all rotation courses lend themselves to online learning. This will allow students to concentrate on other content areas while meeting other familial needs and obligations.
\n
\n Students who have been enrolled in virtual classes all year, please continue to complete
\ncoursework as assigned by your online-teacher.
\n Dual Enrollment students should communicate with their professors for the
\ncontinuation of online learning.
\n GCI students will receive communication from the staff at the skill center on the
\ncontinuation of learning.
\n
\nThe expectation of teachers is to provide learning opportunities that students can do without parent support. Please review these tips on how to create a successful learning environment at home. 
\nWhen you learn in an online setting, you will need to check your District Gmail account every day for information from your teachers and other adults about coursework, lessons, and/or content. All middle school and high school students should check their District Gmail account every day.
\n
\nStudents must check StudentVue and/or their school Gmail account daily to view messages
\n(emails/communications) from teachers. Additionally, students need to reach out to teachers with questions...by email, or during zoom meetings for help, etc. Teachers are here to meet their needs, whatever they may be! Additionally, we have set office hours for our secondary staff. Additional information will be forthcoming from your child’s teachers.
\n
\nMany teachers will be using video lessons and a Google Classroom platform where students can work at their own pace. Additionally, for record-keeping purposes, teachers will create an assignment in their gradebooks and then mark those who participated and who didn’t using the following scale for each assignment:
\n
\n 3 = full student participation and understanding of the content/task
\n 2 = student attempted and understood most of the content/concept
\n 1 = student attempted the content/task but didn’t show a strong understanding of the
\nmaterial.
\n 0 = the student did not participate in the content/task.
\n
\nThese numbers will not be combined to calculate a final letter/traditional grade. All 4th marking period grades for middle school students and second semester grades for high school students will be pass/incomplete.
\n
\nAcademic Information (HIGH SCHOOL ONLY):
\nDue to the executive order per the Governor last week, our school district is moving forward with a PASS/INCOMPLETE grading scale. A student’s GPA will not change with the exception of the following:
\n Students who were failing as of March 11, 2020 are provided the opportunity to demonstrate
\nproficiency in that class. A mark of a “P” for Pass or “I” for incomplete will be recorded.
\n
\nPlease remember that students are STRONGLY encouraged to participate, do their best and complete all assignments. While traditional attendance won't be taken, nor traditional grades assigned, participation will be monitored. Additionally, teachers will still assess, using the aforementioned scale to provide feedback, since that is a best teaching practice.
\n
\nWe understand that not every family has internet access. For those lacking internet access we created a menu of activities that all students can access. These Paper packets will be available for pick up at Central Office (door #11).
\n
\nPaper Packets - FOR THOSE THAT DO NOT HAVE DEVICES OR CONNECTIVITY
\n For students in grades 6 – 12, paper packets via Chicago Series will be made available outside Central Office (door number 11) beginning Monday April 13th at 9am. The first packet is for weeks 1 and 2 (April 13-27). These packets are labeled by grade and you can pick them up at your convenience.
\no Learning packets will be provided bi-weekly.
\n Learning packets will include multiple projects (focused on the core academic
\nareas) to work on independently.
\n Each project can be completed over multiple days, and the projects can be
\ncompleted in any order.
\no Please follow directions on the cover page of all paper packets on how to submit
\nonce complete. 
\n
\nChrome book drive-thru distribution took place on April 8th and 9th for those families that indicated the need from surveys that were put out in past weeks. If you did not receive a device and feel you need one, you can contact techhelp@goodrichschools.org and we will do our best to get you a device. Please realize that we do have a limited number of devices.
\n
\nNo school belongings can be retrieved by students or families at this time, and nothing a student has left at school will be essential for them in completing assignments. The District will communicate more about collecting belongings after the Executive Order, “Stay Safe, Stay Home” has been lifted.
\n
\nWith all the uncertainty we are all facing, communication is more important now than ever before. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us. We’ll do our best to answer you in a timely manner.
\n
\nVirtually yours,
\n
\nYour MS and HS Administrative Team
\nMrs. Kapeka Salter
\nMr. Tom Wozniak
\nMr. Travis McDowell
\nMr. Mike Baszler","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_5","title":"From the Office of the Superintendent (4/3/2020)","content":"
April 3, 2020\n
Dear Goodrich Martian Family:\n
Yesterday Governor Whitmer made the official announcement that to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 and protect the health and safety of this state and its residents, it is necessary to suspend in-person instruction of K-12 students for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.  School buildings must remain closed for the remainder of the school year or until restrictions on public gatherings are lifted.  This means all school-related activities and events will also be cancelled, including spring sports, field days, and class trips.  An exception to this will be prom and graduation.  Details will be made available at a later date.  
\n  
\nAll of our Goodrich staff, from the bus drivers who pick your child up in the morning, to the school secretary who greets them in the office, to the classroom teacher and ancillary staff who provide or support direct instruction and services, are all saddened with the abrupt end of school this year.  Our school buildings may be closed, but learning can and must continue. While students will not be able to attend school physically, Goodrich Area Schools and its staff are committed to providing educational opportunities, through a variety of distance learning methods, so every child can learn and grow.\n
District administration has been busy, since the initial shutdown, developing an evolving plan for the continuation of learning for all Goodrich students. Now that we know school will not resume this year, the educational resources and enrichment opportunities offered to our parents and students will transition.  Our district must submit a formal educational plan that will be reviewed and approved by the Genesee Intermediate School District.  Our building administrators will be communicating with our teaching staff next week to finalize the details of our plan.  \n
Following approval by the Genesee Intermediate School District, we expect to begin implementation of the district’s Distance Learning Plan, introducing learning material to students, on Monday, April 13. Once finalized, the entire plan will be posted on our website.  \n
Per the direction contained in the executive order, all students will advance to the next grade level, unless there were previous concerns about their ability to transition.  There will be individual conversation between parents and the building administrators in those circumstances.  Seniors who were currently on track to graduate, will do so.  Seniors who were not on track to graduate will be contacted by our high school administration and/or guidance counselors.  
\n   
\nFood distribution will continue for students until the end of the school year.  Should there be any changes to the distribution schedule, we will notify you through our district website, email and Facebook page.  \n
I would like to take a moment to thank our outstanding team of teachers and administrators for all they have done to support our students during this difficult time, while juggling their own families, home responsibilities, and their personal concerns about the health and safety of those they love.  \n
We recognize that this communication does not address all of the questions and concerns you have as a parent, or that our students must have about their school year.  Rest assured, we will continue to update you as we navigate through this new “normal” and will provide you with additional details of our plan, going forward.    \n
For now, however; I must reinforce the seriousness of this pandemic and the importance of heeding the Governor's stay at home order. Please do your part to help stop the spread of this terrible virus.\n
Sincerely,\n
Wayne S. Wright
\nSuperintendent of Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_6","title":"From the Office of the Superintendent (3/27/20)","content":"
March 27, 2020\n
Goodrich Martian Family:\n
We are coming to the end of the second week in which the schools were ordered to be closed by Governor Whitmer.  During this very eventful second week we received the “Stay Home, Stay Safe” order from the Governor’s Office.  With this order we have closed ALL district buildings to staff, with the exception of Food Service at the High School where we continue to provide meals on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays from 9:00 to 11:00 a.m.  During food distribution we are also providing packets of work for students.  The “Stay Home, Stay Safe” order also covers use of outside facilities.  We have closed ALL outside areas to include the tennis courts, baseball and softball fields, and the track area until the order has expired.  The Governor has issued this order in an attempt to slow the spread of the virus and we need to abide it.\n
I have been asked on a daily basis if the days we are missing will need to be made up at the end of the year.  The current order expires on April 12 at midnight.  The order could very well be extended as the COVOD-19 pandemic is not expected to hit the high point for a couple more weeks.  I watched Governor Whitmer’s Town Hall meeting last night.  She did not provide a clear answer when asked that question.  The “forgiveness” of school days does take legislative action.  I do not see the Governor saying students will need to attend school all summer.  We need not overreact at this time and let common sense prevail.  I am anticipating we will receive more information next week and when this decision is made we will advise everyone.\n
A memorandum was recently issued by the Michigan Department of Education addressing on-line learning.  The memorandum stated no additional on-line learning programs would be approved and it also indicated no on-line learning programs will count towards the required days and hours of instruction.  We are hoping to receive more information regarding this issue.  Granting credit for classes students were enrolled in at the beginning of this closure are local district decisions. I do not see issues with our students advancing grades or seniors graduating.\n
Teacher are reaching out to students.  Currently there are worksheets and activities posted on the district website which they can access electronically.  Also our administrators are handing out the same enhancement and enrichment materials at our food distribution site.  Additional material will be posted on a weekly basis. \n
At a special meeting on March 19, the Board of Education voted to postpone the upcoming bond election until August 4.  The Board had received requests from the Governor, our State Senator, and local governmental officials to postpone the election.  Upon reviewing all information, the Board felt it was in the best interest of the community to postpone the election until August.\n
The news regarding the crisis does continue to change daily.  I have been a superintendent for 17 years and only once before in my career have I had to deal with an issue as difficult as this.  I am in constant contact with all superintendents in the county and we are working together as we navigate through this situation; working on solutions to provide education to all Genesee County students.\n
I ask only one thing of you, and it is the same thing I have asked of my district staff; I ask for your trust that every decision made is what I believe to be in the best interest of our students and staff at that moment, with the information I have.\n
Please continue to abide by the “Stay Home, Stay Safe” directive and follow the guidelines presented by the CDC.  I know these are difficult times, but the Goodrich community has a reputation for coming together and taking care of one another; it is one of the things that drew me to serving as your Superintendent.  If we work together and support each other, we will get through this crisis.\n
Stay Healthy, Stay Positive\n
Wayne S. Wright
\nSuperintendent of Schools  ","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_7","title":"From the Office of the Superintendent (03/24/20)","content":"
Goodrich Martian Family:\n
According to the Executive Order issued by Governor Whitmer yesterday, all Goodrich Area Schools buildings are closed. The Central and Business Offices will be open in a very limited capacity, in order to continue the essential functions of the district.  We will monitor phone messages and respond to emails.\n
Our Food Service Department will continue to provide meals on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, from 9:00 to 11:00 a.m., to any child in need, aged 18 and under. This service will continue throughout the shutdown, including over the regularly scheduled spring break week.\n
The Governor's \"Stay at Home\" order is in effect until midnight on Sunday, April 12, which means the mandated school closure is now extended until Monday, April 13. We will continue to communicate with you as we learn more.\n
Thank you for your patience and understanding. Please follow the CDC guidelines and the \"Stay at Home\" order from the Governor, to slow the spread of the virus and keep our families safe.\n
Sincerely,
\nWayne Wright, Superintendent\n
\n
\n","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_8","title":"From the Office of the Superintendent (3/13/20)","content":"
March 13, 2020
\n
\nGoodrich Martian Family:\n
At a press conferences yesterday evening, Governor Gretchen Whitmer and State Superintendent Michael Rice, announced that all K-12 buildings – public, private and boarding – are closed from Monday, March 16 to Sunday, April 5, 2020, in order to slow the spread of COVID-19.\n
As a district team, we are working through many items and trying to answer all questions that could arise, as we collectively navigate these unprecedented times and a rapidly changing situation. \n
Goodrich Area Schools will treat this time as an extended spring break.  No academic work will be required of our students, however, optional educational resources will be made available to our families.  Should the shutdown last longer than originally indicated, we will revisit our plan at that time.\n
All buildings in the district will be shutdown.  Pick up of personal belongings will take place today, Friday, March 13, 2020, until 6:00 p.m. for students, families, and staff.  If your child has medication at school that may be needed during this extended closure, please be sure to pick that up today as well.  If your child has any food in their locker, please be sure to remove it.  This is a one-day opportunity for access to these personal items.  After 6:00 p.m., all school buildings will be closed until the expected return date of April 6, 2020.  The Office of the Superintendent will remain open for phone calls at 810-591-2250.\n
Our district website will provide a link to the latest information related to the district’s COVID0-19 response and resources from local, state, and federal agencies.  We encourage our families to visit it frequently. \n
Any families who receive free and reduced lunch and have a need for meals during the closure, can contact Director of Nutritional Services, Mrs. Megan Burny, at 810-591-2236 by the end of the business day on Monday, March 16.\n
All events within the district are cancelled through Monday, April 6.  This includes athletic practices, and games.  The Community Forum scheduled for Wednesday, March 18, 2020, has also been cancelled.  The GHS Theater production of “Working,” has been postponed until further notice.  As determinations are made on any future events, updates will be communicated out and added to our district website. \n
We ask our families to remember the importance of following the recommendations of the CDC and the Genesee County Health Department in order to minimize the risk of exposure for children and families and mitigate the spread of coronavirus.\n
We will always keep the well-being of our school community as our top priority.\n
Sincerely,
\nWayne S. Wright, Superintendent of Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_9","title":"At-Home Learning Survey (3/31/20)","content":"
March 31, 2020
\n 
\nGoodrich Martian Family:\n
With the recent extension of the Governor's \"Stay Home, Stay Safe\" order, it is imperative that we have all Goodrich parents and guardians complete the survey below.  If you have already done so, we thank you for your time and you may disregard this email request. \n
In order to provide educational resources that are accessible and available to all, we must first determine the needs of our students.  This survey will help us conclude the following:\n\n    
Do our families have adequate internet access? \n    
Do our families have adequate devices? \n\n
This data is required from all school districts, by the State of Michigan, and must be submitted to the Genesee Intermediate School District by Friday, April 3, in order to help with planning and decision-making for the remainder of the school year.  \n
Please click on the link below to begin the survey:\n
https://forms.gle/JkrEyaSCCYDisUWc6\n
Thank you for your time.
\nWayne S. Wright, Superintendent of Schools","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl53_divTabs_10","title":"Essential Employees - Covid-19 Minimum Basic Operations","content":"On March 23, 2020, Governor Gretchen Whitmer signed Executive Order 2020-21, which directs all residents in Michigan to remain in their place of residence to prevent spread of COVID-19. The Executive Order continues through April 30, 2020.
\n
\nUnder the Executive Order Paragraphs 4(b) and 7(a)(3), a worker may report to work if the worker’s in-person presence is necessary to conduct “minimum basic operations,” such as ensuring security, processing transactions (including payroll and employee benefits), or facilitating other workers’ ability to work remotely. The order also states that critical infrastructure workers include educators supporting public and private K-12 schools, if operating under rules of social distancing. This exception allows teachers and other school employees to report to school to provide distance learning and to perform other essential functions.
\n
\nSchools must designate those workers who are necessary to conduct “minimum basic operations” and make that designation in writing to the worker. The following employees have been identified as a worker whose in-person presence may be necessary to conduct “minimum basic operations” during the “Stay Home, Stay Safe” order. 
\n
\n
Wayne Wright, Superintendent\n
Joy Moll, Exeuctive Assistant\n

                        scrollToTabEdge: false, // optional - pass in default value for demo purposes
                        disableScrollArrowsOnFullyScrolled: false // optional- pass in default value for demo purposes
                    }).on('ready.scrtabs', function() {
                        $('#'+this.id+' .tab-pane').attr('tabindex',0);
                    });
                };

                activate();
            }
        }
    });

div.p:
To not know how to homeschool your own child
To not know how to work from home
To give kids more screen time than usual
To make a colorful daily schedule or just wing it
To not magically feel motivated to work out at home or take on a new hobby
To not feel okay.
This is not normal for any of us.
Please be kind to yourself (and others)
